conclusion: Understanding the problem involves finding heat exchange Q in a cyclic process of an ideal gas shown in a P-V diagram.
The P-V diagram has volume (V) on the x-axis and pressure (P) on the y-axis with points A, B, C, and D forming a rectangle.
A to B is a horizontal line at P=1 x 10^5 Pa from V=3 L to V=4 L.
B to C is a vertical line down from P=1 x 10^5 Pa to P=0.75 x 10^5 Pa at V=4 L.
C to D is a horizontal line at P=0.75 x 10^5 Pa from V=4 L to V=3 L.
D to A is a vertical line up from P=0.75 x 10^5 Pa to P=1 x 10^5 Pa at V=3 L.
Temperature at point A is 27°C, which is 300 K. Use ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
In a cyclic process, net work done by the gas equals the area enclosed by the cycle.
Calculate work done from A to B: P * ΔV = 1 x 10^5 Pa * 1 L = 100 J.
Calculate work done from B to C: Volume is constant, so work = 0.
Calculate work done from C to D: P * ΔV = 0.75 x 10^5 Pa * (-1) L = -75 J.
Calculate work done from D to A: Volume is constant, so work = 0.
Net work done by the gas in one cycle is 100 J + 0 + (-75) J + 0 = 25 J.
In a cyclic process, change in internal energy ΔU is zero.
From the first law of thermodynamics, Q = ΔU + W = 0 + 25 J = 25 J.
Net work done is equal to heat added minus heat removed, Q_net = Q_in - Q_out = W_cycle.
W_cycle = 25 J, so Q_net should be 25 J.
Verification of work calculation: A to B: P=1e5 Pa.
